title: What are some good horror books for 13 yrs old? - Quora

response.answer_text: Other folks have pointed out some good adult material, Stephen King, Dean Koontz, etc. I’ll mention one of my all-time favs, a sadly overlooked writer today: Christopher Pike. Pike started in the mid-80s and wrote through the 90s (he’s still writing today, but mostly adult fiction). He played second-fiddle to RL Stine, at least in terms of sales. Which is unfortunate, because as much as I like Stine, Pike is a far superior writer. In many ways, Pike’s teen novels foresaw the future YA market: books written in an adult style that didn’t talk down to kids and dealt with legitimate mature themes and situations. There’s plenty of violence, sex, abuse, alcohol, etc. in Pike’s work, as well as heavy concepts like teens dying from cancer and teens dealing with abortion. Now take all that, and throw in the fact that Pike wrote some killer stories. Fast-paced, creepy, inventive, Pike really knew what he was doing. These may be hard to track down today, because they’re mostly out of print (although some of Pike’s trilogies have been re-released in single-volume editions), but here are my favs: The Last Vampire series (re-released as the Thirst series)MonsterRoad to NowhereDie SoftlyChain Letter 1 & 2Master of MurderThe Midnight ClubWhisper of Death

One of the most surprising horror stories for me was Lost Boys by Orson Scott Card (not to be confused with the movie, The Lost Boys). This is a novel that chronicles the relatively unexciting life of a programmer and his small family. The story itself is interesting, but what got me was that when the horror happens you don’t know it. There is no suggestion that anything is out of the ordinary, and it’s only towards the end of the book that you discover it, which completely changes everything you’ve read to that point.
